text:
So I'm excited to talk to you
guys today about a project that is sort of like the most recent
thing that I've been working on.

We don't have a preprint yet. Although I'm hoping in
the next week or two, it will finally be ready
for the light of day.

And I should say, in
terms of questions, I'm very happy for people to
ask questions along the way.

I'm used to teaching MBAs. So you know? Yeah, so any question
at any point, feel free.

OK, so, unfortunately, the
topic of misinformation is something that doesn't
need a ton of introduction.

Obviously, falsehoods
have been around as long as communication
has been around. But in the last
eight years or so,

there's been a particular
form of misinformation that has been getting
a lot of attention, starting during the 2016
election cycle of claims that

are false but presented as if
they're legitimate news claims

and that often are
spreading online. And so there has been a lot
of public concern about this

and a lot of pressure
on technology companies to figure out how to reduce
the spread of misinformation.

And similarly, a lot of academic
research on what to do about it. And the current
state of the art is

there's two main things that
tech companies are using and trying to combat
misinformation, which

is they try to
identify claims that are false or
misleading, either using some combination of professional
fact-checkers and machine

learning classifiers. And then once they've identified
something as problematic, they either can demote
it in the news feed--

so people are just
less likely to see it, which more or less
by definition works-- or they can put
warning labels on it.

And you might be skeptical
about how effective a warning label is. But actually, there's
a lot of evidence

that fact-checker
warning labels work. If you put a label on something
saying that it's false,

people are going to be
less likely to believe it and less likely to share it. We had this review
article recently.

We find across studies,
you get maybe a 25% to 50% reduction in belief in sharing
if you put a label on it.

And there's basically
no evidence of backfire. You might worry that if
somebody believes something

and you put a warning label
on it, they'll get mad, and they'll believe
it even more. But there was one study once
that found that, and then nobody

else ever found it again. But it really stuck
in people's heads. But you don't have to
worry about backfires.

Warnings are good. And I should say the QR
codes are links to papers, if you want to read
more about this stuff.
So this is the state of the art. And in general, demotion works.

And warning labels work. And what the problem
with them is not

something about it not working. The problem with these
approaches and with warnings but more generally with these
content-specific interventions,

where you identify a piece
of content is problematic and then you take
action against it, the problem is
coverage and speed.

So there's so much
content online, that particularly for
professional fact-checkers, they just can't
check everything.

And they can't even
check a tiny fraction of the stuff that is posted. And when things
do get evaluated,

it often takes it slow. I think a stat that Facebook
put out a couple of years ago

was something like
an average of two days between when something is
posted and when it's flagged. Sometimes it can take weeks.

And so, obviously, if something
gets identified and then demoted or flagged
but it's already

been up for days, that's not
going to do anything because, basically, everybody
that was going to see it has already seen it.

So the question is
that-- or the question that I've been
particularly interested in

recent years is, what
can we do to complement these content-specific
interventions?

And in particular, what are
content-neutral interventions that we can do? So things where you don't
need to know anything

about the specific
content that people are seeing in order to get them
to be less likely to share it.

And the work that I'm
going to talk about today takes a particular
approach to this kind

of content-neutral
intervention that's built on insights
that we have had around at least a good chunk of
why people share misinformation.

And so the basic idea
is that social media is an extremely distracting
environment where

you're scrolling quickly
through your news feed. The news is intermixed
with baby pictures and cat

videos and funny memes and all
this different kind of stuff that is emotionally
arousing and also things

where like accuracy
just is not a salient-- how accurate is this cat meme
is not a relevant concept.

And so your attention is
not directed at accuracy. And you're given all
these social signals.

You're seeing who shared
it, how many likes it got, how many comments, all
this kind of stuff. And so because you're scrolling
quickly and you're distracted,

you have limited
attentional resources. And those attentions
are-- that attention is directed at things other
than the concept of accuracy.

So even if you're
someone who doesn't want to share inaccurate things-- and so you've got a preference
that says, if it's inaccurate,

I don't want to share
it-- you don't wind up acting on that preference
a lot because you just forget to think about it
because you're thinking

about all this other stuff. And so what this lens on
misinformation sharing

suggests is simply
getting people to consider the
concept of accuracy, just shifting
attention to accuracy

will lead you to be more
discerning or sharing and, in particular, will make
people less likely to believe--

or, sorry, less likely
to share a false claims and particularly less
likely to share claims

that if they thought about
it, they would realize were not true. So if there's some falsehood
that's widely believed,

this isn't going to help,
because people will think about it and say, oh, yes, it's
accurate, and share it, anyways. But there's a lot of
claims that people

are sharing, that if
they thought about it, they would realize are not true. And in particular, the
social media context

selects for stuff
that's a little bit sensational or
salacious or whatever that doesn't pass a little
gut check because that's

what makes it spread. If you can make up truths-- or, sorry, you could
make up falsehoods that everyone would
think is true,

but they would be
totally boring, and no one would ever
want to share them. And so the same thing that
gives a lot of the fire

to successful false
or misleading claims

is what would make you
realize on reflection. Well, maybe this
is kind of fishy.

So we've run a lot of
survey experiments testing

this proposal. And so we've looked at a lot
of different ways of directing

people's attention to accuracy
at the beginning of the study. A thing that we've
done the most is

what we call a
evaluation prompt, where at the beginning
of the study, we say, first, we want to pretest a
news headline for future studies

we're interested in, whether
people think it's accurate or not. We show them one
nonpolitical headline. And we just say,
in your opinion,

how accurate is this headline? And then they go on
to the main task, where we show them a
bunch of posts like this

and say, how likely
would you be to share it? But the idea is because we
asked them about accuracy

once at the beginning, it
primed the concept of accuracy. And so they're more
likely to think themselves on the subsequent posts, oh,
well, how accurate is that?

And across a bunch
of these studies-- well, actually, we
consistently find

that this makes people
less likely to share the false claims. We've also done it using
minimal digital literacy

tips like this card here. This is from a paper that Ziv
Epstein, who's a postdoc here,

was the lead on. I think these tips don't
really teach anybody anything that they didn't know already.

But just reading it makes
you think about accuracy and be like, oh, yeah, I
guess I should pay attention. You can ask people how
important is it to them

to only share accurate content. Most people will
say very important or extremely important. And then they'll go on
to be like, oh, yeah,

I guess I should be
thinking about that. You can also tell
people that other people think that it's important to
only show accurate content.

And so as I said, we've
run a lot of experiments of this structure. And we had this paper
a couple of years

ago where we did a meta-analysis
of 20 different experiments that we ran with over 26,000
American participants, in which

each of them had a control
condition where people just went through a bunch of actual
posts-- some true, some false--

and said whether
they would share it or a treatment where something
was done at the beginning to prime them to
think about accuracy,

and then they did
the sharing task. And we find that
on average, they're prompting people to think
about accuracy at the beginning

reduce the sharing
of the false-- or the sharing intentions of
the false claims by about 10%

and had no effect
on the true claims. And an important thing
to emphasize here is that these accuracy prompts
aren't giving any people

any new useful information. It's not telling them anything
about the specific pieces of content. It's not telling them what's
true or what's not true.

It's just activating the concept
of accuracy in their mind, shifting their attention
to accuracy, such that

then they using their own
facilities, essentially, think about it more afterwards.

So we found that it works for
political headlines you agree with, political headlines
you don't agree with,

COVID headlines. It works for conservatives
and for liberals. And it works-- we have
hundreds of different headlines

across all these different
experiments and dozens of different ways of prompting
people to think about accuracy.

And we consistently
find these effects. We also had a paper we
published last year where we

did a cross-cultural studies. We use statements about
COVID-19 that were relevant everywhere in the world.

And we looked at 16
different countries. And we did the same procedure.

And we find, similarly, on
average, across countries, there was like a 9.4%
decrease in sharing intentions

for false claims when
you prompted people to think about accuracy. No effect on true claims.

And then we also had a
small-scale Twitter field experiment, where we found
about 5,000 users that

had shared links to
low-quality news sites. And we sent them
a private message doing the exact same
treatment, where we say,

here's some random headline,
how accurate do you think it is? And then we looked at what
they shared in the 24 hours

afterwards. And we found it significantly
improved the quality of what they were retweeting.

So this is kind of like the
background for what I want to talk to you about today.

This is what we've spent
the last four years doing or whatever. Yeah, one question on-- I know I-- I think I
know the answer to this,

but I've forgotten. Do you know how long this
inoculation tends to last? And I know you get
this question a lot. Yes, so this is an
important question

that is very hard to answer in
the survey experiment context. Because when we have them come
and do the survey experiment,

the experiment takes five
minutes or something like that. And we don't see
evidence of decay over the course of
the five minutes

that they're doing
the experiment. But that's not that impressive.

Because the Twitter field
experiment, you did track it. Right, so in the field-- with the Twitter
field experiment,

in order to do the causal
inference in a clean way, we use what's called a stepped
wedge or randomized rollout

design, where everyone
got the treatment. But you randomized who got
the treatment on each day.

So each day, another chunk
of people get the treatment. And so that means-- and then you compare
in that day the people

that got it to the people
that didn't get it. But it means that for
the first 24 hours,

you have data from everyone. But for each 24 hours out,
you get less and less data because you have less of a
control condition to compare to.

So basically, we weren't well
powered to look beyond 24 hours there. But one of the key
insights from what

I'm going to talk about
today pertains to this. So let's return
to that in a bit.

Have you noted whether
or not it matters if the headline is presented
with a picture or a video?

Yes, so in this
particular context, we haven't crossed the accuracy
prompt with whether there

is a picture there or not. But we have done
some experiments. We had some old stuff
published on this.

And Zivvy ran some
experiments a year ago that never wound up writing up. We're also did headline without
picture, headline with picture.

And it didn't really
make much difference, which was contrary
to our expectations. But yeah.

I don't know if you said
this-- people were not allowed to use external
resources to just solve

the problem that was there. Or were people allowed
to be like, wait, let me Google this too? So we didn't tell them not to.

But in these survey experiments,
nobody cares enough to do that. Whereas in the Twitter
field experiment,

who really knows what
people are doing? They're just out there in
the world doing their thing. But my sense is
most people don't care enough even in real
life to Google things

to find out if
they're true or not. But it's more,
you're scrolling by. And you're like, oh,
that looks funny. All right, I'll
retweet it, whatever.

And I should say that as someone
that studies this and spends all my time thinking about this,
I have done this myself,

where I know at least once, I
retweeted something because I thought it was amazing. And then a couple of hours
later, one of my colleagues

responded and said,
is that actually true? And I was like, oh,
I did the thing.

Yeah, but I think that your
question does highlight one of the real limitations
of all of this stuff, which

is the focus of what I want
to talk about today, which is there's a ton of this evidence
from survey experiments

where the outcome is
sharing intentions. People are in this artificial
lab context where they're clicking through
qualtrics surveys

and on each page
being like, well, how likely would I be share it? How likely would
it be to share it? And we've done some
other work that

suggests that these self-report
sharing intentions are meaningfully related to what
people actually do in the world.

But the question
is, if we really were going to do this at scale
on platform, what would happen?

How well would this
actually work in the wild? And so that's what I
want to talk about.

And so the question is, how
could we deliver this at scale?

Obviously, if we
were technology-- if we were Meta, we could
just build lots of things

into the platform that
are always reminding people about accuracy. But that requires a lot
of engineering lift.

And so we wanted to figure out,
as a-- not as the vision of this is the ultimate
implementation, but as a way

to in a minimal effort way test
this at scale, what could we do?

And the answer that we
came up with is ads. And a lot of the way that we
came to this idea actually

is some nonprofits that
do like election integrity type stuff got
interested in this work.

And so they hired a design
company to make a series of ads based on our research.

And then during
the 2020 election,

they bought a lot of ad space
on disinformation websites with these kinds of ads. And they found that
they were getting

way more engagement than
their typical persuasive ads. And then so during the Georgia--

the runoffs, they spent a ton of
money like millions of dollars putting these ads
all over everything. Got tens of millions
of impressions.

And based on a survey
experiment we ran on YouGov, there's reason to
think that this reduced the sharing of misinformation.

But they were not doing
credible causal inference about-- they were just
running an ad campaign.

And so we wanted to know,
OK, let's do this for real. Let's try and do a real
randomized experiment

using these kinds of ads
and see what happens. And, OK, why do we think
that this might work?

Well, as maybe is
not surprising given that that's the whole
business model of the whole--

of the social media,
there is evidence that social media ads work.

And so there was this
big meta-analysis of more than 600 ad
experiments on Facebook.

Oh, yeah. Yeah, yeah.  And they found that in general,
the media and ad campaign

increased sales like bottom
of the funnel outcomes, as they say in
marketing, by about 5%.

In the public health context-- or the public policy
context, there was this paper that did
a meta-analysis of all

of the COVID vaccine
public health like PSA type experiments
that were run on

or campaigns that were run
on Facebook and Instagram. And they found an average
of about a 1% improvement

in attitudes towards
COVID vaccines as a result of being
in the ad campaign.

And then there was this paper
by the people at Acronym, which was this nonprofit that
was started by a bunch of people

that left what was at that
time Facebook to go try and do election integrity stuff.

And so they basically were doing
pro-Biden persuasive ad campaign that they spent
millions of dollars on.

And it lasted eight months. And it decreased turnout. And they had assessment where
they had a randomized holdout

group and stuff like that. And they found that the ad
campaign reduced turnout among likely Trump voters
by 0.3 percentage points

and increased turnout
among likely Biden voters by 0.4 percentage points. So the point is--

I think the key
take home from this is social media ad
campaigns can move behavior.

And these are the kind
of magnitudes of effect that you should expect if
things are working the way we

hope they would work. And so we want to
know, can accuracy prompt ads reduce
misinformation sharing online?

And what we did in
this paper and what I'm going to spend the
rest of the time telling you about is two
experiments that we ran.

One run on Facebook, and one
run on Twitter that are--

both involve using
accuracy prompt ads to-- showing accuracy
prompt ads to people

and looking at the effect on
their sharing of misinformation. And beyond that, they are
different in every other regard.

So they're complementary. I'll start with the
Facebook experiment.

So this is an experiment that
was conducted by researchers at Meta plus Nils
Wernerfelt, who

is a professor at Northwestern
now but was at Meta at the time.

And I was the
external person that worked with them to
design the experiment, but they actually ran it and
analyzed the data and so on.

And so we recruited 33
million Facebook users, which was a general
population sample plus--

because misinformation sharing
is actually not very prevalent. And so to try to increase
the amount of signal

that we would have, up
sampled 350,000 users who had shared misinformation
links about two months before we

ran the experiment, which
at the time at which they selected the user set.

And then people were randomly
assigned to either a control or to treatment. And the people
within the treatment

were randomized into one of
three different treatment arms that had used
different creatives. But whichever arm they
were within the treatment,

basically, what it
translated into is they got about three ads where the
normal ad that Meta would have

showed them was replaced
with an accuracy prompt ad. And so that happened
for about three ads

over the course of three weeks. So roughly one ad per week,
which is not very much.
And we will return to that. So they showed these ads.

And the ads were Meta branded. And so this is what
they looked like.

People in one arm got
one of these three sets of digital literacy tips. And the other
ones, I don't think

they're really teaching
anything because it says, like, two tips for
thinking critically before sharing an article. And then it's got some
small thing down here

that I think nobody reads. And so the point is what you get
from this is think critically.

And then when you share
an article how important is that it's accurate,
80% of Americans think it's important to
only share accurate things.

Some stories contain emotional
language, check for accuracy, this sort of thing.

So they get one of these ads. And then we want to know how
much bad stuff are they sharing.

And the key outcome,
obviously, is going to be like, are they sharing posts
that are misinformation,

and how much does the sharing
of misinformation post compare control
versus treatment? And so the key question
in all of this research

always is, how do you define
what counts as misinformation? And so for this experiment,
we had three signals.

The first is things that
professional third-party fact-checkers flagged
as false or misleading.

Another thing is Facebook
has this program called Community Review, where they
have a representative group

of Facebook users that
reviews content, basically that does crowd-based
fact-checking.

We have a whole other line
of work on that incidentally. I should just say, crowds are
remarkably good at identifying

misinformation. And we found that a crowd
of maybe 15 or 20 people can get as much agreement
with fact-checkers

as fact-checkers have
amongst themselves. So we've got the crowd signal. And then Facebook
has a-- or Meta

has a classifier
for Facebook that tries to predict what's
misinformation or not.

And so we've got all
three of these signals. And of course,
the caveat here is

this is an estimate of
what's misinformation and what's not misinformation. It's very far from perfect.

But I would say, it's much
better than most past work and the Twitter experiment that
I'll talk about in a minute, where if you don't have a
classifier the way that--

the way Meta has on hand, what
almost everybody else does is they just use the domain
as a proxy for quality

and say, oh, well, if it's
from the New York Times, we're going to count it as true. If it's from Infowars, we're
going to count it as false.

And that's the best we can do. So here, we're doing better
than that because it's at least something
about the actual post. And also, it's not
restricted to URLs.

This is any post goes in there. And these ads, they're
always empty, right?

Yep. OK, yeah. Just depending on where the
ad would have been before, that's where it is. Exactly, it's using-- it's like
Facebook's standard brand lift

type machinery where
you pay to run your ad, and they substitute it in
and keep track of who saw it.

And then in the brand
lift, they follow up with some questionnaires. Here, we just follow up
by watching what they do.

So you have no control
over where the ad is. So it's not like you
don't know if it's the first thing that they see
versus it's just like somewhere

in the middle of the
viewing experience. That's right. And it must-- almost always,
it's going to be the latter, I think. And so that's another thing to
keep in mind in interpreting all

of this is, undoubtedly,
a large fraction of the people that
were treated were not actually treated and
just scrolled by the ad

and never looked at it. And so that's also why I
say, whatever we see here, if Meta wanted to do this,
they could presumably

produce much larger
effects by making sure that the people
actually saw the things.

So as I mentioned
briefly before, misinformation sharing
is low on average. This is like now a
well-reproduced result

across a bunch of
different studies. And we also find that here. So if we use all
three possible flags

and say if it gets any-- if the
fact-checker said it was bad or the crowd said it was bad or
the classifier said it was bad,

any of those things, we're
going to call it bad. Still, in the week before the
experiment, only 6.5% of users

shared any bad claims at all. So 93%, 94% of people were not
sharing anything bad at all.

And even among the people
that did share at least one problematic
thing, 60% of them

only shared one
problematic thing. So in order to get
the most signal here,

we're going to just
pull all the flags. Say, if it's flagged on any of
the different misinformation things, we're going to
call it misinformation.

And our key outcome is
just going to be a 0, 1, Did the user share
anything bad or not?

which is essentially
like doing a median split on misinformation sharing. It's going to be
like, no versus yes.

And we basically just have
one observation per user, which is like, during whatever
window we're looking at, did they share anything bad?

And we're going to compare
treatment versus control. And-- Yeah, sorry.

I missed it. What is pooling
all possible flags? That is whether it's flagged
by third-party fact-checkers,

by a community review,
or by the classifier. If any of those things are
true, we're going to say it's 1. And if none of them are true,
we're going to say it's a 0.

OK, and are you only
looking at the 6-ish percent that shared something?

Well, I'm going to start
by looking at everyone. And then I'm going
to subset on the 6%, and things will look better.

Was that-- Are they just given news
headlines or misinformation

embedded in other ways like
memes and things like that? It's everything. And unlike most
other work where you have to rely on the
domain classification

and, therefore, it's
only URLs, here, it's just like all posts
that are identified.
OK, so what happened?

I'm going to start by
just looking at the effect within the Facebook browsing
session in which the ad was

delivered, either the
treatment or the control ad. And to do this, I'm going
to look at the 60 minutes--

what people share
in the 60 minutes following the first prompt
or control ad that they got.

And about 80% of users are no
longer active after 60 minutes.

And what we find is a 1.8%
reduction and the probability

of being a misinformation
sharer in the treatment relative to the control. So that's something.

But as per the
question before, it doesn't really make
sense to be looking

at the 93.5% of people
that probably weren't going to share anything bad, anyways. If the person was not going
to share any misinformation,

giving them a prompt
is not going to help. And so if we only subset on
the people who shared something

pre-treatment-- that shared something
bad pre-treatment, we get a 2.6% decrease in
their probability of being

a misinformation sharer. And you get totally no
effect at all among the users that didn't share anything
pre-treatment, which,

again, makes sense and is in
line with what you would expect.

And so in what I'm
going to tell you next, I'm just going to focus
on that 6.5% of people that actually shared some
misinfo pre-treatment.

We don't really find-- we don't find any
significant difference across the three
different types of prompts

that we show to them, which is
consistent with what Zivvy found in survey experiments,
where compared

a whole bunch of
different prompts. And they all basically
work equally well. As long as you're directing
people's attention

to accuracy, like, great. And we didn't find
any interaction

between the treatment and a
bunch of different covariates. That is to say, it
was equally effective

regardless of user
gender, age, or education. And age is a particularly
notable one because previous

work-- and I think we
replicate this here-- finds that people over
65 are substantially more likely to share misinformation.

And so if this didn't
work on those people, that would be a
problem, but there's no significant interaction. And to the extent
that there is one,

it's directionally in
the direction of a bigger effect for the old people. So that's good.

So then I would say, the older
folks are still sharing more. But this is helping
them perhaps more,

at least as much as the other
people, but maybe more even. Exactly. That'd be amazing. Exactly.

And then this is also consistent
with what we find in the survey experiments, where we don't find
much moderation of this effect.

It seems to work pretty well
for pretty much everyone-- or pretty equally for everyone.

We also don't find any effect
on sharing of nonmisinformation content, because that's another
problem is say this reduced

misinformation sharing. But it reduced all other
kinds of sharing too. Then the tech companies
would be like, thanks,

but no thanks,
which made me say, anyways, but that's
a different issue.

So there's no significant effect
on the total number of posts,

excluding misinformation posts. If you do an equivalent model
looking at the number of misinfo posts, there is a
significant decrease

in the number of misinfo posts. And the interaction
is significant. So it's saying, this
effect on misinfo posts

is significantly smaller than
the effect on nonmisinfo posts. So evidence that the effect is
specific to the kinds of posts

that we actually want to
reduce the sharing of. OK, so that was in
the first 60 minutes

after you get the
first treatment. What about over the full
three weeks of the campaign? Maybe not surprisingly,
there's no significant effect.

But remember, they're only
getting about one prompt a week. And if this is about
redirecting attention,

it seems to me it's sort
of unreasonable to expect that you get a little
thing that prompts you to think
about-- that focuses

your attention on accuracy. That session, you log off. You go live your life. You do all kinds
of other things.

And then the next
time you log on, you're not still
thinking about accuracy, whatever else happened to you.

And so the-- and also ad
effects are small in general. And sharing over three weeks,
the high variance outcome.

So the question is, what happens
if instead of just doing one a week, we prompted people
a lot more regularly?

And so this brings us to
the Twitter experiment. And the Twitter
experiment was run by us
with no help from Twitter.

And Hause Lin is
this great postdoc in my group, who is the
technical lead on this stuff.

And what I'm going to
show you is the results of pooling three
different experiments that we ran that is essentially
three different rounds of data

collection. In the first one, we
sampled about 33,000 users

who had shared links to
low-quality domains in the week

before we ran the experiment. And here, the domain
quality, which I guess I'll talk about on the next

but basically, we've got
these fact-checker ratings of thousands of domains. And we use those as

The second experiment

of Canadian truckers. Because two of my

So we were like, all

And we randomly

of these different

And the people that were

And what it came
out is on average, people saw 2.9 accuracy
prompts per day every day

for the duration
of the campaign. But we didn't want people
to start ignoring them.

If you show this person the

like, well, I saw that, I'm going to ignore it. So we had a set of 50
different creatives.

And we're just randomly
sampling from that set so that people
wouldn't ignore it.

And unlike the

Twitter-branded ads.

They were branded

is called thinkaccuracy.

And is the news you're

can tell true from false. Trust your judgment. Think first.

Some of them were the

These minimal digital

And so in this study, we don't

It's like habituation. Right, exactly. And I think the reason we were
not getting habituation here is because we had this

And it's not like we were

And so I think that's

Like, banner blindness
is a huge problem. And so you have to
design in a way that doesn't have that problem.

And also, like the
Facebook experiment, we found no significant
effect on sharing of nonmisinformation posts.

And we found that the effect
was significantly more negative for misinformed posts
compared to not misinfo posts.

So again, it's the evidence that
it's specific to the bad posts.

Finally, we also had a
fourth Twitter experiment, where the people
that we targeted

were largely inactive users. So these were
people that had not shared any low-quality

had shared at least one

longer in the past. Most of these people
didn't tweet anything at all in the
pre-treatment days.

And not surprisingly, it didn't
do anything for these people. And this experiment--
the effect here

was significantly
different than the three that did target active sharers. And again, this is emphasizing
the importance of targeting this

at the people who are
actually the problem and not the people that are not
doing anything, anyways.

So that's what we did. And to wrap up, I just want
to contextualize these effect

sizes. So remember, what motivated this
whole thing is all these survey

experiments we ran
where we showed people hypothetical social media feeds
and asked for their sharing intentions.

And in that context, we know
exactly which posts are true and which posts are false,
because we picked them,

and we have complete control. We know exactly what
people are exposed to. We know everyone
receives the treatment because we give it to them.

And there, we're getting
about a 9% to 10% decrease in sharing intentions. And in the real
field study where

there's all these problems like
as you asked earlier, probably most people didn't
even see the ad.

It was just another ad in the
feed that you scroll right by. So probably a lot of people
didn't get the treatment. There's this
imperfect measurement

of which outcomes
they're sharing are actually
misinformation or not.

There's also potentially
interference effects, which is to say, if the
people in the treatment are sharing less
stuff, it's possible

that people in the control were,
therefore, seeing less stuff and also sharing it. My guess is there's not much
interference because the effects

aren't that big. But whatever. This is all reasons that
you should expect the field experiment to be smaller
than the survey experiment.

And I was actually extremely
pleasantly surprised that the difference
was a factor of 2 to 3

rather than a factor of like 10
to 100 or something like that. So I think the effect
sizes compare favorably

to the survey experiments. And also, this 2% to 6% is in
line with the ad experiments

that I told you
in the beginning, that in general, these social
media ad experiments are effects on roughly this size.

And then something that we don't
capture in this experiment-- but if you imagine
that this was happening in the world, the real impact
would be bigger than this.

Because first of all,
there's network effects, like I was saying a minute ago. If I don't share it, my
followers don't see it,

none of them share
it, and so on. And also, to the extent
that your sharing behavior-- even if you don't have
very many followers,

your sharing behavior is
informing the algorithm about what content
is interesting and what content it
should show to people.

That also can-- if you
take that into account, it can amplify these effects. And as I think I
mentioned earlier,

we're just using the
ad delivery platform because it was convenient. But you could do things that
make sure that people actually

see the ads. And then you presumably
would get bigger effects. So I think overall, the idea is
these are meaningful effects.

But if you're a platform,
you're balancing the effect of this against costs. Like, if you're replacing
ads with these things,

you're costing you ad revenue. So another reason
that probably ads are not a good way to do
this if you're actually Meta.

So to conclude, I
think this is evidence that accuracy prompts can
actually reduce misinformation

sharing in a meaningful way
in real field experiments at scale on platforms. So this is like a real thing
that could actually work.

And these interventions
are content neutral. You don't have to know ahead of
time what is the bad content.

And so it fills
this important gap left by the content-specific
treatments that

are the current mainstay
of anti-misinformation interventions. And here, we have this
convergent evidence

from experiment on Twitter
and an experiment on Facebook that are different in
all of their details,

despite having the
same overall goal. So that convergent
evidence makes me more confident in the result.

And I think one of the
key practical implications is it's not enough to show
somebody an accuracy prompt once

and then go away. If you want this
to work, you need to have a sustained
redirecting of attention. And I think the platforms have
created an environment where

at default, the attention
is on not accuracy. And so it needs to be some kind
of like regular or continual

efforts to get people to be
thinking about accuracy if you want this to work. But fortunately, it looks
like people don't just

start tuning it out. So that should actually be
possible to do sustained redirection of attention.

And also, it's important
to only target users that you would expect to
share misinformation largely

although that means that the
treatment is content neutral,

but it's not user neutral. And so you still
need to be doing-- you need to have some
information about who

are the people that are
potentially problematic and then target them. So which has some
practical issues

and also potentially
is something that people could feel is
discriminatory, although I would

argue relative to all other
kinds of interventions, I don't think it's
a very strong case

to make that this
is discriminatory, because you're not forcing
anybody to do anything. You're just helping
people actualize

their actual preferences,
which is not sharing things that are inaccurate. Or also, you could do
this in times of crisis,

where you have likely to
think that most people might be sharing inaccurate things
because there's a lot of it out there or whatever.

And again, just to
reiterate, we use the ads for simplicity of designs. But there are other modes of
delivering this that could

likely generate larger effects. So thanks a lot. Thanks to all of the many
people that worked on these.

These are the folks

and Gourds at Cornell side. So thanks a lot.
